tags.inscription: PERRY DOUGLAS ROE 1863 – 1926  P.D. Roe was Port Moody’s first mayor. From 1913 to 1915 (and again from 1918 to 1923). He arrived in Port Moody as a young cowboy from the American south, and became on the community’s leading employers (Co-owner, Canadian
tags.name: Perry Douglas Roe

tags.inscription:
DR. CHARLES RITCHIE SYMMES
1875 – 1946

Dr. Charles Symmes practiced medicine in Port Moody from 1909 to 1946. He regularly rowed across the inlet to Ioco to see patients. Born in Quebec, he was bilingual, and was sometimes called upon to attend patients
tags.name: Dr. Charles Ritchie Symmes

tags.description: A two-sided stone memorial on the US–Canada border commemorating the centennial of the Oregon Treaty of 1846.
tags.inscription: In commemoration of the centennial of the signing of the Oregon Boundary Treaty of 1846 // This monument was erected jointly by Canadians and Americans on the international boundary line which has always remained unfortified and undefended. The symbol of
tags.inscription:en: In 1819 an international agreement provided for the joint Anglo-American occupation of the Oregon Territory–the country west of the Rocky Mountains between 42°N and 54°40' N. By 1843, however, the conflicting claims of American settlers and British fur tr
tags.inscription:fr: Une entente internationale détermina en 1819 l'occupation anglo-américaine conjointe de la côte nord-ouest de l'Amérique entre les 42° et 54° 40' parallèles. Mais l'expansion de la colonisation américaine se heurta bientôt au commerce britannique des four
tags.name: Oregon Treaty Centennial Monument
tags.operator: Historic Sites and Monuments Board of Canada

Stand Density Trials

The corner of Mary Hill Road and Wilson Avenue, where you stand now, has special significance in the history of Port Coquitlam. This site was designated a heritage site on December 9, 1985 by the City of Port Coquitlam and has two claims to fame. (cont.)

tags.description: A 300 year old Douglas Fir tree was named "Charlie's Tree" after a World War I veteran Charlie Perkins planted ivy at its base and lay wreaths on it to honour his fallen First World War pilot friends. Charlie Perkins, who died in 1986, moved to the Fraser
